No, basically it's flight by having independent thrust control on each engine. You thrust one engine more than the other to keep it balance and it's controlled by high end computers. It's not unprecedented in the real world, certainly not science fiction.

This is not quite the same, but closely related in principle, to how the B2 bomber flew without a tail. In that case, it was computer controlled thrust vectoring, so the engines would change their thrust direction to stabilize the craft. I'm not sure, it may have had independent throttle control to help too. It would certainly make sense.

It's probably less science fiction than some of the stuff we have in the stock game (LV-N).
